metadata.sermon_start_end: Imagine the Ethiopian eunuch. We have to imagine, because there is so much we are not told about him. We are told some things. He was a eunuch. He is from Ethiopia. He is in the Gaza Strip. He was a Jew, come to worship in the Jerusalem temple [...] Can you imagine what it was like that day in the chariot, on his way back to his old work, but now totally different? Such love casts out fear!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses Acts 8 as a narrative frame, but it relies heavily on 'homiletical freedom' to fill in gaps not present in the text. Dekker's demand for what is found 'NOWHERE else' is undermined by the preacher's focus on general psychological archetypes (fear vs. love) rather than the specific scandal of the eunuch's status or the specific Christology of the Isaiah scroll.
quotes: So with a bit of homiletical freedom to set up the case, let us imagine...
Is it too much to conclude that he lived in a world of fear and innuendo...
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus less on 'imagined' court intrigue and more on the specific theological necessity of the eunuch's inclusion in the New Covenant as a fulfillment of the specific Isaiah passage he was reading.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The exegesis is speculative. Instead of exploring the historical-religious context of a eunuch in the temple or the specific Hebrew/Greek nuances of the 'humiliation' mentioned in Isaiah 53, the preacher projects modern bureaucratic anxieties onto the first-century context.
quotes: I imagine he read the scroll in a context of fear for his job...
He knew about treatment like a sheep for slaughter, because his own life was cheap.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Utilize the required knowledge of Hebrew/Greek and biblical history to explain why a eunuch reading Isaiah 53 is a specific 'present' of revelation, rather than using him as a mirror for modern workplace stress.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding the 'zeitgeist' (National Security State, James Risen), which Dekker values. However, it risks becoming a general political lecture on 'fear' rather than an application of the specific Word of God. It borders on the 'general truths' Dekker forbids.
quotes: A decade of fear-mongering has brought power and wealth...
Fear makes us do crazy destructive things. Fear turns neighbors into competitors.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Anchor the critique of the 'culture of fear' more directly in the specific promises of the Acts text rather than external political commentary.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon successfully avoids the 'block' structure. It moves fluidly between the eunuch's story and the contemporary world of the hearer. The hearer is 'expounded' alongside the text.
quotes: We are all seduced to dwell, along with the eunuch, in that cottage of fear.
The eunuch had had enough of that world. He dove into the gospel world of love...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Ensure the 'mixing' doesn't lead to the text being swallowed by the application.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The structure of misery (fear), redemption (baptism/love), and gratitude (rejoicing/new policies) is present. However, 'misery' is framed more psychologically/sociologically than as misery 'before God'.
quotes: The eunuch was caught in a world of fear.
He dove into the name and story and truth of Jesus that is about love.
He introduced new policies... neighborly management.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect to include the theological lostness of man, not just his psychological anxiety.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon presents a choice between the 'world of fear' and the 'world of love'. It touches on 'temporal loss' (society perishing), but lacks the ultimate seriousness of the 'two ways' regarding man's destination before God.
quotes: In an instant he made the move from a world of fear to a world of love.
The news is that the culture of fear is a fraud and we need not consent to it.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the 'ultimate possibilities of life design' more sharply. The choice feels more like a lifestyle improvement than a matter of life and death.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: While Jesus is mentioned, he is presented as an 'agent' of 'transformative love' or a 'name/story'. The doctrine of the two natures is absent. Christ is more of a moral example or a catalyst for a new 'worldview' than the ontological Savior.
quotes: He told him about the release of transformative, healing love released into the world through this single agent.
He told him that Jesus had only one command, that you love one another.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Present Christ as the 'telos' who is God, rather than reducing the 'Good News of Jesus' to a command to love.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 14.5 minutes (1450 words), the sermon fails Dekker's 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for 'depth'.
quotes: The narrative is so terse. Nothing is explained or even commented upon.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical and dogmatic weight to meet the 20-minute threshold required for substantive proclamation.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its brevity and its tendency to substitute psychological/political analysis for rigorous biblical exposition. It relies too heavily on 'homiletical freedom' to invent a backstory for the eunuch, which distracts from the specificities of the text. The Christology is thin, leaning toward a social gospel of 'love vs. fear' rather than a proclamation of the two natures of Christ and the objective reality of grace.
strengths: Effective interwovenness of text and contemporary context.
Strong awareness of the zeitgeist and the psychological state of the modern hearer.
Traceable movement through the triad of misery, redemption, and gratitude.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (under 20 minutes) prevents theological depth.
Christ is presented as a moral agent of love rather than the divine Telos.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an engaging religious speech, but it is not yet a 'sermon' in the strict Dekkerian sense. It lacks the necessary breadth (length), exegetical depth, and high substantive weight of dogma required to recreate the Bible into a current, proclamatory Word of God.
